previous_headings: I Want To Contribute > Reporting Bugs
title: Contributing to ggret
text: good bug report shouldn’t leave others needing chase information. Therefore, ask investigate carefully, collect information describe issue detail report. Please complete following steps advance help us fix potential bug fast possible. Make sure using latest version. Determine bug really bug error side e.g. using incompatible environment components/versions (Make sure read documentation. looking support, might want check section). see users experienced (potentially already solved) issue , check already bug report existing bug error bug tracker. Also make sure search internet (including Stack Overflow) see users outside GitHub community discussed issue. Stack trace (Traceback) OS, Platform Version (Windows, Linux, macOS, x86, ARM) R Version, runtime environment Possibly input output Can reliably reproduce issue? can also reproduce older versions?

previous_headings: I Want To Contribute > Reporting Bugs
what: How Do I Submit a Good Bug Report?
title: Contributing to ggret
text: must never report security related issues, vulnerabilities bugs including sensitive information issue tracker, elsewhere public. Instead sensitive bugs must sent email gerdspecht1995@gmail.com. use GitHub issues track bugs errors. run issue project: Open Issue. (Since can’t sure point whether bug , ask talk bug yet label issue.) Explain behavior expect actual behavior. Please provide much context possible describe reproduction steps someone else can follow recreate issue . usually includes code. good bug reports isolate problem create reduced test case. Provide information collected previous section. ’s filed: project team label issue accordingly. team member try reproduce issue provided steps. reproduction steps obvious way reproduce issue, team ask steps mark issue needs-repro. Bugs needs-repro tag addressed reproduced. team able reproduce issue, marked needs-fix, well possibly tags (critical), issue left implemented someone.

title: Contributing to ggret
text: Make sure using latest version. Read vignette carefully find functionality already covered, maybe individual configuration. Perform search see enhancement already suggested. , add comment existing issue instead opening new one. Find whether idea fits scope aims project. ’s make strong case convince project’s developers merits feature. Keep mind want features useful majority users just small subset. ’re just targeting minority users, consider writing add-/plugin library.

what: How Do I Submit a Good Enhancement Suggestion?
title: Contributing to ggret
text: Enhancement suggestions tracked GitHub issues. Use clear descriptive title issue identify suggestion. Provide step--step description suggested enhancement many details possible. Describe current behavior explain behavior expected see instead . point can also tell alternatives work . may want include screenshots screen recordings help demonstrate steps point part suggestion related . can use LICEcap record GIFs macOS Windows, built-screen recorder GNOME SimpleScreenRecorder Linux. Explain enhancement useful ggret users. may also want point projects solved better serve inspiration.

title: Visualisation of Tree-based Phylogenetic Networks with ggret
text: first step, recommend getting ggplot2 CRAN ggtree Bioconductor haven’t done previously. ggret package available via GitHub can installed remotes package.
code: # Install ggplot2 install.packages("ggplot2")  # Install ggtree if (!require("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("BiocManager")  BiocManager::install("ggtree")  # Install ggret if (!requireNamespace("remotes", quietly = TRUE))   install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("grdspcht/ggret", dependencies = TRUE, build_vignettes = TRUE)

title: Visualisation of Tree-based Phylogenetic Networks with ggret
text: ggret provides parsing functions building upon ape::read.tree treeio::read.beast reading extended Newick BEAST2 NEXUS files network blocks. input data stored evonet treedata objects can used plotting analysis. next step tutorial, instead use retnet_treedata object also comes package. treedata object corresponding (summary) phylogenetic network simulated BEAST2 package Bacter containing various node metadata.
code: library(ggret)  #read_enewick parses extended Newick format and generates an evonet object.  retfile_nwk <- system.file("extdata" , "retnet.nwk", package = "ggret", mustWork = TRUE) retnet_evonet <- ggret::read_enewick(retfile_nwk)  #read_beast_retnet parses BEAST2 NEXUS files and generates a treedata object. retfile_nexus <- system.file("extdata" , "retnet.nexus", package = "ggret", mustWork = TRUE) retnet_treedata <- ggret::read_beast_retnet(retfile_nexus)

title: Visualisation of Tree-based Phylogenetic Networks with ggret
text: ggret central function package. simple call without additional arguments plots visual representation phylogenetic network. first use original ggtree function plot backbone tree retnet object  now plot entire network, including reticulation edges, using ggret function.

what: Changing the aspect of reticulation edges
title: Visualisation of Tree-based Phylogenetic Networks with ggret
text: ggret functions can take different arguments change aspect reticulation edges.
code: # Reticulation edges displayed as red dotted lines, in a "snake" shape p1 <- ggret::ggret(retnet_evonet, retcol = "red", retlinetype = 3) # Reticulation edges displayed as blue solid lines, in a straight shape and with arrow heads p2 <- ggret::ggret(retnet_evonet, retcol = "blue", retlinetype = 1, arrows = T, rettype = "straight") # Plot plot(p1) plot(p2)

title: Visualisation of Tree-based Phylogenetic Networks with ggret
text: Adding geom_tiplab geom_nodelab ggtree previous call allows us annotate network metadata stored retnet object. example add tip labels posterior support values nodes. Note expand x axis limits make tip labels visible.  another example add time axis plot, well node heights’ 95% highest posterior density intervals represented bars. example requires phytools package.
code: ggret::ggret(retnet_treedata) +    ggtree::geom_tiplab() +   ggtree::geom_nodelab(aes(label = round(posterior,2)), vjust = -0.25, hjust = 1.2, size = 3) +   ggplot2::expand_limits(x = 23000) # Get the tMRCA of the tree and define time points to display in the time axis in years BP library(phytools) tmrca <- phytools::nodeHeights(retnet_treedata@phylo) %>% max xticks_BP <- c(20000,15000,10000,5000,0)  # Plot the network ggret::ggret(retnet_treedata) +   ggtree::theme_tree2() +   ggtree::geom_range(aes(range = "height_95_HPD"), color = "grey50", alpha = .6, size = 1.5) +   ggplot2::scale_x_continuous(breaks = tmrca - xticks_BP, labels = xticks_BP) +   ggplot2::xlab("Years before present")

title: Visualisation of Tree-based Phylogenetic Networks with ggret
text: group_clade can define clades within network use aes color accordingly. group_clade assigns clade information nodes descending MRCA tips specified nodes argument. value taken specified cladename argument added clade attribute evonet object , addition, Clade column data component tree data objects addtotreedata argument set true.
code: # Define clades using the group_clade function retnet_treedata %>%   ggret::group_clade(nodes = c("taxon_10", "taxon_20"), cladename = "A", addtotreedata = T) %>%   ggret::group_clade(nodes = c("taxon_11", "taxon_15"), cladename = "B", addtotreedata = T) %>%   ggret::group_clade(nodes = c("taxon_1", "taxon_16"), cladename = "C", addtotreedata = T) ->   retnet_clade  # Plot network with colored clades ggret::ggret(retnet_clade, aes(color = Clade))

title: Visualisation of Tree-based Phylogenetic Networks with ggret
text: use ggret, please cite associated publication well original ggtree publication: ggret publication added G Yu, DK Smith, H Zhu, Y Guan, TTY Lam*. ggtree: R package visualization annotation phylogenetic trees covariates associated data. Methods Ecology Evolution. 2017, 8(1):28-36. doi: 10.1111/2041-210X.12628.

title: Fortify evonet objects — fortify.evonet
text: model evonet object convert data frame data original data layout Currently 'rectangular' layout supported ladderize TRUE reorganizes backbone tree get laddered structure right specifies whether smallest clade right left branch.length specifies branch length attribute mrsd specifies mrsd attribute .Date specifies .Date attribute yscale specifies y scale attribute root.position specifies root attribute ... arguments passed methods

code: ggret(   data,   mapping = NULL,   retcol = "black",   arrows = FALSE,   retlinetype = 2,   rettype = "snake",   na.rm = TRUE,   mrsd = NULL,   as.Date = FALSE,   yscale = "none",   yscale_mapping = NULL,   ladderize = TRUE,   right = FALSE,   branch.length = "branch.length",   root.position = 0,   xlim = NULL,   layout.params = list(as.graph = TRUE),   hang = 0.1,   ... )

title: Plot reticulation networks — ggret
text: data either treedata evonet objects mapping aesthetic mappings retcol reticulation edge colour arrows TRUE reticulation edges end arrows retlinetype line type aesthetic reticulations rettype Either 'straight' 'snake'. Determines style reticulations drawn na.rm supresses NA value warnings mrsd recent sampling date .Date logical whether using Date class time yscale Y-Scale yscale_mapping Y-scale mapping category variable, ladderize Logical (default TRUE). tree re-organized 'ladder' format? right Logical. ladderize = TRUE, ladder smallest clade right-hand side? See ape::ladderize() information. branch.length Variable scaling branch. root.position Position root node (default = 0) xlim X-Axis limits. layout.params Layout parameters list format hang Defines hang ... additional parameter
